content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												I've only played this one and the original Scribblenauts, so it's possible that this is what all the current games are like, but ...The basic idea of Scribblenauts is that you are let loose in a series of levels, each of which contains a "Starite." As Max, your goal is to obtain the Starite by any means necessary. Fortunately, you are armed with a magic notebook; when Max writes nouns the game understands in the notebook, whatever he's written is summoned into reality. With Scribblenauts Unlimited he gains the ability to use adjectives, as well, even adding them to existing objects.In the first Scribblenauts game, getting the Starite usually (but not always) required solving a physics puzzle. In Scribblenauts Unlimited, though, you generally just end up walking up to an NPC, being told the NPC wants something, and then writing down examples of whatever is requested.For instance, an NPC might be described as a "Hungry Vegetarian." Write down "apple" "pancake" "carrot" get Starite. (That was off the top of my head, but it might actually be in the game. That's the level of sophistication.) It's less a video game and more a vocabulary test. Oh, and since a LOT of puzzles require knowledge of English-language culture, don't even expect to be able to use it to help learn the language.It doesn't help that in the first game Max would often find himself in danger and need to find a way to protect himself. Here, the first thing you do in each level is click on Max and add adjectives like "Immortal Flying Fireproof" to yourself and then roam with impunity.Basically ... if the first Scribblenauts was easy, Scribblenauts Ultimate barely qualifies as an activity book. An expensive, overproduced activity book.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												Frankly, it was an honest effort. I'll give them that. But Scribblenauts just didn't catch my attention. Sure, I got 3 hours into it, but I have at least 10 times that in CS:GO, let alone the 60 TIMES record I have in Garry's Mod.      It's enjoyable for the begginning, and I'm sure younger audiences might play this game for months upon months, but when you suddenly turn 13 and realize there's games like Call of Duty out there for you to play, the replay value drops rediculously. Better than nothing, but I'm just not left satisfied. 4/10 stars.Auther's Note(s)     With all due respect to the hours upon hours it must of taken to make Scribblenauts, it just isn't worth the money I put into it. And I even got it on sale. It's fine if you're younger though, so if you've got a 5/6 year-old brother or sister that wants something to do, it's considerable to buy it for them.

Posted: September 1, 2014
												7/10I know that this is supposed to be a game for younger players, because the puzzles aren't really hard when your brain has reached a certain age and knowledge, but it's the perfect opportunity to mess around with an almighty notebook that spawns nearly everything you want.Throwing stuff into a blackhole? Check.Dinosaur-riding zombies with laser guns? Check.Radioactive vampires fighting ninjas? UNDERWATER? CHECK!If only it didn't have this comicbook style...But as I said before, this is "a game for kids", it's supposed to teach them proper spelling, common sense and other stuff, and that's why it gets boring-to-look-at for (most) people who are older than 12.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2013
												A cute looking problem solving sand box game that involves spawning, labeling, destroying and manipulating objects and entities with an educational angle for kids. The premise is simple with multiple objectives in each map, but the possibilities and combinations are limitless and often hilarious, with many shards and starite objects to collect once all objectives have been met.For achievement hunters, the full starite collection will require trying a huge selection of outfits, weapons, items and situations, but the process is relatively fun if, albeit, slow. Good fun for kids. 3.5/5

												I remembered playing this on my Nintendo DS and it was fun but lack much clearer directions than this one. And now i finally got to play this IP again and this time on PC! This version if more refined and polished in terms of controls, content, storytelling & gameplay but to sum them all up has given that charm that i haven't experienced in a long time since Little big planet, Locoroco and their likes. Simple and dose not stress your brain to think too much i would say.Surprisingly, one of the best games i've played this year to the point that it's going to be one of my GOTY of 2013. Yes i'm that serious! I would recommend myself to play this game with my future kids one day :).

content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
												Scribblenauts Unlimited is a fun game which allows for an amazing level of creativity in what the player can make. Making use of Nouns and descriptive words makes the creation of objects in the primary game rather fun, and the ability to create your own objects in the game makes it even more fun. The creation of objects is easy to use and doesn't have many issues, but it would be best to avoid altering the hit-box parts too much, as it could cause unusual problems.

Posted: June 21, 2014
												To sum up this review right away, I will say this is one of the funnest time-wasting pseudo-sandbox games I have ever played. Now onto the real reason why:Scribblenauts has you playing Maxwell, a little boy with the ability to make anything appear, change, shift, etc. with his handy dandy notebook. His sister Lilly is sick with some weird disease so he has to go out into the world and find little shards of star thingies called "starites" which will hopefully make her all better. This game is part messing around with whatever strikes your fancy (aka a sandbox), part puzzle, and part adventure. It also requires a little bit of thinking and creativity to get past some head-scratching or seemingly impossible tasks. This game is designed to tap into the ingenious little child you once were, where the possibilities to accomplish anything were endless and only limited by your imagination. You need to get a ball off an old man's lawn without touching the lawn itself? Fly yourself over the lawn in a helicopter and pick it up! Need to get past a killer robot? Dress yourself up in a suit of armor to deflect the attacks! The art is adorable, the animations seemless and what is humorous to note is to watch how the objects you've brought to life interact with other objects, creatures, and people long after you've set them free or completed a mission. I find myself accidentally unleashing less-than-friendly little beasties on the unsuspecting populace, much to their depleting heart bar and my wry schadenfreude.  The music also fits well with every place you go, perfectly setting the tone to where you are and what you're doing. I have not had the chance to mess with the object editor but from what I can tell by popping in and taking a look around it only adds to the possibilities of further customization of your little adventure.It is at times so easy to earn starite shards that I sometimes feel like I'm progressing too fast and not enjoying it for what it is, namely a pleasant time-waster, as I've said before. Personally, I find that you can tell a lot about yourself by what beings you bring into the Scribblenaut world to solve your problems. For "man's best friend" I always type in some breed of terrier, and when I can afford to I always use sponges to clean stuff up. Is it familiarity or my lack of thinking outside the box that makes me lean towards these choices? Who knows.This is a fun game that unlocks the imaginative kid in all of us, and for kids that know their way around a computer this is the perfect game for them to play, too.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 14, 2015
												A fantastically fun puzzle game. The solutions are unusually easy for the genre, but the unique mechanics give you an incredible range of creative options to work with, encouraging you to think outside the box and go crazy with all sorts of alternate solutions. Thanks to the low difficulty, this allows the game to function equally well for kids who are learning to think critically or adults who like being creative.  MechanicsWriting. Yep, that simple. You’re presented with a puzzle, you think of what object you need to solve it, you write that word, and poof! you’ve created that object. You can also add adjectives to objects to give them different traits, which is required by certain puzzles. The in-game dictionary is respectably large, with everything from generic items to everyday objects to all sorts of professions to all the major pantheons to a variety of oddly specific animals & plants. There’s a surprisingly complex system of interactions built in between different items. Scarecrows scare crows, devils are instantly killed by holy water, honey badgers kill everything, war can be defeated by a white dove, the large hadron collider can create a black hole, combining a cat & toast destroys the universe . . . the possibilities are endless and often contain hilarious references. You can tell that a ton of effort went into this. However, there are a few hard limits on what you can’t create. Namely, nothing sexual or vulgar. It’s marketed as a family game, after all. Though in typical American fashion, the game will allow you to be surprisingly violent without raising an eyebrow. Scribblenauts Unlimited will let you set packs of children on fire or get people to cannibalize each other or feed babies to raptors or any other manner of creative atrocities, but you can’t dare have exposed nipples. Think of the children!The rules for proper nouns are also somewhat confusing. For the most part, proper nouns are a no-go, but there are a few exceptions for famous people and some other random things. Not many and not very consistent, but they’re there. The lack of consistency can be annoying – only a small handful of world-famous names actually give you anything, yet the entire dev team produces valid entries. They made sure that Cthulhu is in there, so at least they got that much right.The Starite Vision mechanic makes it super easy to find the puzzles in each level, meaning that you’re never left lost and looking around for where to find more shards (which was apparently a problem in the first game). Of course, the PC version of Scribblenauts Unlimited allows modded dictionary words, which people diligently use to add their favorite celebrities or ponies or Pokémon – a treasure trove of items for the dedicated player.   The game also possesses a free-roam adventure aspect to it, as you can run around the map and just have fun. There’s a bit of a fighting system in there, so you can shoot or hit other characters . . . or light them on fire or turn them nice or set off a nuke and kill everyone or suck the world into a black hole or whatever you want.  You can spawn pretty much any item and apply whatever adjectives you want to things, meaning that the ability to express yourself as you play is endless. Everyone gets to play the game their own way, and that’s the most beautiful part about it.Level DesignVery elegant for the type of game it is.  The main quest simply requires you to go around completing puzzles until you've collected 60 starites. There’s substantial wiggle room built into the main quest, as you only need to earn just over half of all the possible 106 starites in the game. So while a completionist can explore the entire game and have fun collecting all of them, a younger or lazier player need only explore the puzzles that they can actually figure out. Thus the game remains fun and kid-friendly by letting them learn and express themselves without being punished for getting stuck on specific puzzles.Every stage has two types of challenges present in it: starites and shards. The shards are simple puzzles that usually only require you to create a single item to solve. They reward a shard – several of which combine to form a starite, giving you a slow but steady way to collect starites. The starite puzzles are larger, self-contained little scenarios that consist of several puzzles chained together. They’re more elaborate and have way more attention to detail placed into them.  They take longer and are sometimes more difficult, but completing them gets you a whole starite right away. Each stage will only have 1 or 2 starite puzzles, but a bunch of shard puzzles. This gives a really nice balance to the game, and makes the starite puzzles feel like special treats that break up the normal gameplay of steady shard collection through simple puzzles. You can also earn shards (and achievements) by performing unique & creative actions in the world, which incentivizes players to explore and have fun creating things. NarrativeMaxwell & Lily are a pair of siblings with world-famous explorers for parents. Their parents pass down a magic notebook to them – you can write anything in it and it makes it appear! Maxwell & Lily are sent out into the world to explore, but immediately abuse the power of the notebook to pull a prank on a poor old man. The old man curses Lily and encases her in a slowly-growing tomb of stone, revealing that this curse can only be broken by the power of starites. Since starites are released by happiness, Maxwell has to rush out and use the power of the notebook to make as many people happy as fast as he can, in the hopes that he can save Lily in time.It’s a pretty simple kid’s story with a strong Aesop about using your abilities to make the world a better place. It works really well, especially for the sort of educational game this is. Maxwell learns that playing dirty tricks on other people is bad, and that he should use his talent to bring joy to the world instead. For adult players, the game is absolutely FILLED with jokes. Tons and tons and tons of subtle little jokes and references to all kinds of things, in particular nerdy properties. It’s surprisingly funny. I caught myself laughing out loud all through my playthrough.  AestheticsVery pretty. The entire game has this goofy cartoonish look, like everything is made from construction paper and pinned together – the sort of thing a kid would make during playtime. It’s a super solid, cohesive art design. Reinforces the fact that the game is played with your imagination more than anything else. And the levels have a wide variety of styling, with different zones linked together by shared art to create a world that feels “real.” The only voice acting in the game is during the opening and closing cutscenes, but it’s well done. Really injects some feeling into what is otherwise a simple story.  David Franco’s music is great at reinforcing positive emotions. The level themes are relaxing, helping the art to create a soothing atmosphere for a fun puzzle game. The main menu theme is impressively upbeat, creating a joyous mood as soon as you start the game. Then there's the rewarding jingle you get for winning a starite – composed of 110% "feel good."Makes you just want to go collect more starites. Overall Rating:  5/5

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												The fun of Scribblenauts isn't in solving the puzzles. It's in solving them in the most horrible way possible that the game will let you get away with. Once I figured that out, it wasn't long before I realized that my little Scribblenaut character was not in this for the sister-saving heroics. Oh, no. Beneath that cute little hat and grin lurked the dark heart of a sociopath. A boy who dared to ask the questions that most sane people would never consider. A boy to whom even Cthulhu bows. Chaos incarnate.Some men just want to watch the world burn. And for our little Scribblenaut... A flamethrower is just a quick scribble away. God help us. God help us all.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												Pros- Silly, fun, creative. Definitely a different gaming experience. Gaming is enjoyable trying to puzzle through the characters problems and also just messing around with the engine typing in “evil giant mecha flaming pink zombie” and “massive good magical flying paladin” then giving them swords or guns and watching them duke it out. Lots of stuff in the workshop to download to play around with. The different zones are well thought out and visually appealing. Cons- Sometimes when you write in a solution to a problem ex. to fix a tire you need a “wrench” but the actual answer is “mechanic” it may take a couple of tries of perfectly fine answers until you get to the one the game wants. Multiplayer would have made this game even better. If I were being nit picky I would say I would like more complex problems and more combination or crafting stuff in the game.

												I bought this for $60 when it came out.[screams internally]If you liked Scribblenauts on the DS, then you will like this game. It does have a lot of content in the way of puzzles, but they are not particularly stressful or challenging; don't expect a Dark Souls experience is all I'm saying. You really can create anything... as long as that something is not a proper noun or copyrighted material. But then there is the Steam Workshop and the Object Editor, which allows your imagination to go wild.If I bought this game for $10-20, then that is a good deal for what is essentially an object creation sandbox. There might be some limitations in the way the objects interact, but all in all it is a good game toy. But $60 was highway robbery. Fun while it lasted.I give it 7 out of 10 transparent zombie purple immortal starites.

												The main character Maxwell can summon objects with his magic pen and paper to help people he mets on his journey. Sounds simple, eh? Well there's thousands of objects to be summoned, from a simple bird to Cthulhu to God himself. The sky's the limit. Simple colorful visuals and tons of possibilities makes this a very fun way to spend a few hours.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 6, 2012
												Great, fun puzzle game with interesting sandbox gameplay.  Solve puzzles by creating objects using words or adding whatever adjectives you can think of, and there is more than one way to solve any single puzzle!  If something doesn't exist, you can create it on the object editor!I recommend this if you like platformers, and/or love creating whatever your imagination can create.  Not as complex as gmod (that's because gmod of course, is more specialized in sandbox gameplaym than scribblenauts), but that doesn't mean Scribblenauts is limited!  Create sparkling rainbow bazookas that fire exploding panties,or flying pigs or a flying chair you can ride...whatever is on your mind!  Every object you make can have behaviors, scripting for more advanced behaviors, making anything ride-able, edible, hold-able, wearable...whatever!  And every object can be edited as well.It's quite surprising what things exist in the game you never expected to be there.  Of course, would be nice to see more things done with the game, but still a fun game nontheless, well worth the 30 bucks spent.   If it's on sale, definitely get it!

												Very cool game, rather simple but relatively complex all at once.  The story is sweet, and the unique, colorful graphics make it pleasant to look at.  It's really amazing how nearly any word you come up with can be used in some way, and it's fun to come up with the craziest and most creative solutions possible to the puzzles you're presented with.  Very replayable considering each puzzle has hundreds of possible ways to be solved.  All around a very awesome game.

												An amazing and fantastic journey into a colorful world of hilarious hijinks and crazy antics, Scribblenauts Unlimited is the first game in its series to allow players the opportunity to create their own objects to summon and play with! With the Object Editor, you can change what an object does, how it looks, how it reacts to other objects, and so much more! I highly recommend this game to anyone who likes a little creativity in their diet, and hope that more people can experience Scribblenauts Unlimited.-LogCollie

Posted: April 10, 2013
												This game looks like it's just for kids, but is in fact awesome.  Gameplay is quick to learn: you type the names of what you want to summon (it has a rather expansive database of words that surprisingly includes 'ginormous'), it appears.  You solve puzzles by summoning things that are appropriate to the situation...help the janitor get rid of spills by summoning a flamethrower, give the fat kid a chocolate dog, make yourself a jetpack when you get bored of walking.  Open ended and entertaining--buy this game.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
												I definitely recommend this game to people of all ages! Scribblenauts Unlimited is simple enough for younger folk, but at the same time, it's great for adults as well. There are so many ways to get creative and just have fun with your surroundings. Basically, you play as Maxwell and your goal is to help your fellow man with a magical notebook in order to save your sister. The different worlds and the people/creatures who inhabit them are so fun to interact with. I'm not sure about what's available in the Steam Workshop, as I have yet to try out any of the custom content. I love this game, but I do have only one complaint: the game can get repetitive at times if you decide to use the same solution for multiple puzzles.

												This sequel to Scribblenauts is truly a technically impressive feat, but it is very offensive to someone who is a radical Muslim such as myself. In this game, you play a boy who can create anything by writing it in his magic book, including a huge variety of living creatures - which become even more diverse with the new adjective system. The Koran says that only Allah can create life. Often times the game encourages cannabilistic activities, and this is against the word of Allah as described in the Koran, unless of course the subject in question is an enemy fighter or an adulterer. However in the case of Scribblenauts, you are prompted to feed a cannibal at a restaraunt, and the only way I could continue is by feeding him a fried baby. Truly a disgraceful game to our great creator. 2/10 would jihad again.

Posted: November 13, 2013
												The best in the series yet! Scribblenauts Unlimited is fun game for everyone, kids, and elders alike. If youve never  played a scribblenauts game, then this one is a great start for you. Scribblenauts can be described by one word, creative. Basically in the game, you have a magical notebook in which you can write (or type) in almost anything you want. Thats right anything, such as medusa (the greek mythology character), or another thing would be cthulhu ( the sea monster). There are also adjatives you are able to add to anything. An example of this would be creating a giant spoon, and then adding the adjetives ridable, or flying. This would then make it so you can ride the flying spoon around the world.                              Super Fun and creative!                               For all ages!                              8.7/10!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 23, 2012
												Scribblenauts is a game about writing words. The words you write will be created. You can use this to solve puzzles if you're lame. If you're not you will create a pile of hats, wear them all, laugh gleefully, then force a ninja hamster to fight against a samurai cactus. There will be people caught in the crossfire. Lots of people. After this, you will call forth the 4 horsemen of the apocalypse to clean up any survivors. Having experienced the greatest thing ever you will then probably die yourself.After that you can do puzzles I guess.Why are you even reading this anyway? You either love Scribblenauts or you think its a poorly executed gimmick. If you like Scribblenauts this is for you. I obviously love Scribblenauts.But even if you don't like Scribblenauts it has all the hats. All of them.And with the new Object Creator, if there's a hat that doesn't exist you can MAKE YOUR OWN HAT. Then you can upload it to the Steam Workshop so everyone can experience the glory that is YOUR HAT.10/10

												Okay, it's silly, but what did you expect? This game is much more addictive than I thought it would be, and I was very surprised to see how much time I've spent playing it (and usually procrastinating doing very important things at the same time). The challenges are usually very easy to complete, which may put some people off of the game, but there are also many creative ways to solve puzzles - finding new ways of solving the same puzzle can be a lot of fun! Overall, it's a fun game that is useful for burning time (so I strongly reccomend it to those who have just finished exams and have a very long holiday ahead of them!).

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												Fun little puzzle/sandbox game.  You basically control a guy who solves puzzles or solves people's problems using his magic notebook.  Whatever you write comes to life, such as "rabbit" or even "evil giant purple rabbit".  While a lot of the tasks/quests/missions given to you are pretty much straightforward, the great part about this game is being able to try something weird or unexpected to accomplish the task, usually with hilarious results.For example, for "Give the little kid something to help him get past the bully" I wrote "gun."  A pistol spawns in his hand and the bully runs away scared.Additionally, you can just goof around in each level, messing with the inhabitants, making weird things, etc...It's a game you will eventually finish and probably get bored of later, but if you want a very casual and easy game with some unexpected laughs, give this a try!  It's also good kid-friendly, and also a good game for non-gamers to try out.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												Scribblenauts Unlimited is a game that you use your imagination and wit to solve puzzles and problems for other people, creatures, etc. The general story is that Maxwell, the protagonist, and his sister, Lily, have been given very powerful tools, a Notebook that creates what you write and a globe that teleports you around the world, that have caused them to become somewhat rotten. Their parents sent them out to learn about the world, Maxwell pulls a rather mean trick on a beggar, and the beggar casts a spell that turns Lily slowly into stone. Maxwell learns that Starites, a product of people's happiness, can possibly return Lily to normal. Thus your quest begins.Basically restating the introduction aside, you go around the world solving people's problems using your magic Notebook. Now the real fun of the game is that your objectives can be solved in the most random of ways. Somewhere in the game, you are tasked to get something that would make noise for a Fire truck. You could go with a regular old siren, but why not use the mythological one? And it counts. As for Maxwell himself, he has a life-bar, so you do need to be careful when going around or you can die.One of the downsides to the game, however, is that you can severely cheese it sometimes. Using the notebook, you can use the adjectives invincible, fast, and flying on Maxwell to make him as such. It's nice when you're just fooling around and whatnot, but it does take away an aspect of possibly surviving.You can also create your own custom objects using an editor within the game. You're also able to try out others' creations in the Steam Workshop as well as put your own out to share with the world. I haven't played around with the editor myself, and I have tried to import items from the Workshop with no success, but it could just be on my end.There was some controversy with this game for a little while when the developers were sued by the creators of Nyan Cat and Keyboard cat for using their intellectual properties in the game without consent. Not sure how the lawsuit worked out and there was a decent amount of debate on who was right and who was wrong; none of this really effected the game itself to my knowledge.Overall, Scribblenauts Unlimited is a pretty good game that can last you as long as your imagination can. I'd advise picking it up when it's on sale.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 11, 2012
												This is undoubtedly the definitive version of Scribblenauts. It’s especially well-suited to PC, with the mouse for precision item-building and placement, and the keyboard for quick, no-fuss item generation. Furthermore, the object editor adds some extra depth to the experience, offering creative folk the opportunity to create abominations that act as they deem fit.Starite collection isn’t mindless in this instalment; while fleeting, there has been an effort to give meaning to Maxwell’s journey. His life and family’s history are also delved into. The premise of Maxwell’s grand quest is odd, but charming in a way: Maxwell’s twin sister, Lily, is cursed by an old beggar whom Maxwell played a trick on. Starites, apparently, are able to stop Lily’s body from petrifying, so Maxwell sets out to do good deeds and acquire the cure for his sister. Along the way, Maxwell will run into all forty of his other siblings—that’s right, Maxwell’s folks have forty-two kids. The siblings are an eclectic bunch, and once found, may be used instead of Maxwell as the playable avatar. The other siblings don’t add depth to the plot, but they’re fun to find nonetheless. The level editor from previous games has been replaced with an object editor, which allows the player to create *virtually* anything, although they must start with a base object (Eg., “Cat”). Thereafter, the base object may be adorned with whatever suits the creator’s whim, and colours and textures offer added appeal. The editor also enables the player to alter/add/remove a wide range of behaviours and attributes, which can have hilarious or disastrous results. Usually the latter, but that only adds to the fun. The object may also be renamed, and that name need not stick to any naming conventions. 5th Cell have done away with linear progression and opted for something far more versatile; perhaps the most welcomed change to this version of Scribblenauts is the player’s ability to traverse the large overworld in an unrestrained fashion. While they will need to collect a certain number of Starites to unlock neighbouring chunks of map, the available chunk of map contains several areas the player can discover at their own leisure, in any order they choose. One can skip the trek and simply select each area from the map menu, though there seems to be greater reward in discovering each area on foot. Scribblenauts Unlimited is full of curious and sometimes head-scratching puzzles, all of which are a delight to solve. For the first time, players are able to create their own objects to solve puzzles and/or hassle NPCs—both equally fun. Players are offered a lot of freedom in this game, which is another first, and definitely a step in the right direction. My only quibble is the complete lack of multiplayer, or a level editor that can be used to create scenarios for friends to stumble through.

												STRONGLY recommend this game. I thought it was some girly and childish game similar to Little Big Planet series. I was so wrong! This game really gives you the feeling of being a godlike being with your magical notepad. It's a little bit like Deathnote's notepad which allows you to write out how you want someone to die and when - only that this is even more powerful, it goes beyond death and can even create things and make things change properties. For example if I met an angry man I could take out my magical notepad and write that he is a crazy happy guy, and boom he becomes that! Really really fun for those who have great imagination. Alas, this is still not a game for everyone. The graphics are still pretty cute and some serious gamers may never swallow it. Or that you are not the very creative kind and prefer hard action etc.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 30, 2012
												The premise is simple:  imagine anything, and watch it come to life in the game.Scribblenauts at its core is a sandbox word game that gives its players the freedom of imagination to produce and create almost anything they can think of into the game in order to solve problems and puzzles.  Cat stuck in a tree? Write, "ladder," and "fireman" and watch them appear in game and save the cat.  Soldier in need of a weapon?  How about typing in "bazooka," or "laser gun," or even "Excalibur" or "Thor's Hammer" if you want.  It's all in the game, and it'll all work towards solving puzzles.  The game really is almost limitless, with the dictionary of recognized words limited mostly by one's imagination, and it makes it a lot of fun just to aimlessly type things in, watch them come to life, and mess around.Scribblenauts is the kind of game that prides itself in creativity in addition to its undeniable charm.  It's great for any and all ages, and also is a true go-to game that I like to show off to non-gaming friends and family.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2012
												Great, fun puzzle game with interesting sandbox gameplay.  Solve puzzles by creating objects using words or adding whatever adjectives you can think of, and there is more than one way to solve any single puzzle!  If something doesn't exist, you can create it on the object editor!I recommend this if you like platformers, and/or love creating whatever your imagination can create.  Not as complex as gmod (that's because gmod of course, is more specialized in sandbox gameplaym than scribblenauts), but that doesn't mean Scribblenauts is limited!  Create sparkling rainbow bazookas that fire exploding panties,or flying pigs or a flying chair you can ride...whatever is on your mind!  Every object you make can have behaviors, scripting for more advanced behaviors, making anything ride-able, edible, hold-able, wearable...whatever!  And every object can be edited as well.It's quite surprising what things exist in the game you never expected to be there.  Of course, would be nice to see more things done with the game, but still a fun game nontheless, well worth the 30 bucks spent.   If it's on sale, definitely get it!

content:
Posted: April 13, 2014
												An amazing and fantastic journey into a colorful world of hilarious hijinks and crazy antics, Scribblenauts Unlimited is the first game in its series to allow players the opportunity to create their own objects to summon and play with! With the Object Editor, you can change what an object does, how it looks, how it reacts to other objects, and so much more! I highly recommend this game to anyone who likes a little creativity in their diet, and hope that more people can experience Scribblenauts Unlimited.-LogCollie

content:
Posted: April 10, 2013
												This game looks like it's just for kids, but is in fact awesome.  Gameplay is quick to learn: you type the names of what you want to summon (it has a rather expansive database of words that surprisingly includes 'ginormous'), it appears.  You solve puzzles by summoning things that are appropriate to the situation...help the janitor get rid of spills by summoning a flamethrower, give the fat kid a chocolate dog, make yourself a jetpack when you get bored of walking.  Open ended and entertaining--buy this game.

content:
Posted: April 4, 2014
												After finishing this game I can certainly say that is is worth playing. It has replay ability but its mostly about the first play through. If you are playing I'd say keep an eye on the shards in the menu, otherwise you'll end up at the end grinding for ages to get the shard pieces. Its fun to write some random stuff to solve odd puzzles that in most cases can be solved simply but why solve it simply when you can summon kathulu or a giant pink fish or a tiny tank. Games like this bring out the weird and sometimes darker parts of my personality. There are some problems where I had to look up on Wiki to find out how to complete a task but for the majority you can find some way to 100% the game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 12, 2014
												Scribblenauts Unlimited is a fun little game where you can let your crazy imagination run wild.  If you want a flying blue explosive transparent friendly sofa or a rideable polka-dotted glass bright coffee cup, then go ahead.  The only limit in this game is your imagination (or copyrighted things).  The whole purpose of this game is to help people out by spawning things in with your magic notebook and fixing their problems.  If you're ever in a bad mood and you want to feel better, this is the perfect game to play.  Probably the best feature about this game is the object editor and Steam Workshop integration.  You can easily edit any item and post it to the Steam Workshop for anyone to enjoy.  If you find an item that someone else has made, you can download it from the Workshop and put it into your game.  From a completionist standpoint, this game is really easy to complete considering the majority of the achievements are from collecting starites.  If you've ever wanted a game that was really easy to 100% complete, Scribblenauts Unlimited is your game.  I rate Scribblenauts Unlimited a 8/10.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 15, 2014
												There's a moment early on in Scribblenauts when you're faced with a puzzle with an entirely easy solution. Instead of that solution, you want to do something creative and crazy. The idea is in your head, but you know it won't work: there's no way the game developers even thought of putting a <insert thing> in the game, and if they did, they wouldn't have made it a way to solve this puzzle. And then it works.That moment is different for everyone, and describing mine (giving a theremin to a homeless guy so he could start a band) wouldn't really explain what makes it so special. It's a moment everyone needs to experience for themselves.Scribblenauts is a sandbox game. Sure, there are puzzles, achievements, and even a plot, but for the most part Scribblenauts is a game where you want to put the craziest things into the world and see what happens. The puzzles facilitate this well: any adult should have no problem solving them (they are, after all, designed for young children), but if you're like me you will find yourself motivated to think of the most ludicrous solution, with the hope that maybe you can outsmart the game. Need to put out a fire? Firefighter is a boring answer; try annihilating it with some antimatter!Playing out pure sandbox fantasies is amazing too. Watching what happens is what makes the game amazing. Give God a magical squirtgun and he'll use it to turn Cthulhu into a dove—then promptly discard the weapon, pick dove Cthulhu up by the neck, and start bashing him on things. It's an inexplicably amazing experience.The game shines when your crazy ideas play themselves out, but it's not perfect at it. Finding the holes takes a little magic away each time, and reminds you that the game can't actually function without being programmed to. If something is missing in the game you might be able to find it in the Steam Workshop (or build it yourself), but it's doubtful it will be quite as epic as finding that yes, the developers did in fact think of it.My main criticism is the adjective system. While it's amazing when it works, and it can be a lot of fun to add an adjective to a random citizen and watch them change their behavior because of it, it's not without fault. Many if not most of the available adjectives seem to have minimal effects short of thought bubbles expressing them, if they even have that. Why doesn't my "vengeful" hunter attack people? What makes her vengeful? Further, some objects do exist in the game that are multiple words, and making these is tricky when the game assumes if you have a typo you meant to type "Adjective Noun" instead of a two word noun. Some of these are entirely confusing: "flying broomstick" is a seperate object from spawning a broomstick and adding the adjective flying to it, for instance.Still, these moments hardly detract from the rest of the game. It's an amazing and well worthwhile experience.

												The game is cute and the puzzles are fun. It's neat to come up with outlandish solutions to the puzzles though sometimes I overthought some of the puzzles and actually got stumped.
